natural problem: How many paths are there from $A$ to $B$, if every step must be up or to the right?[asy]size(4cm,4cm);int w=6;int h=5;int i;pen p=fontsize(9);for (i=0; i<h; ++i){draw((0,i) -- (w-1,i));}for (i=0; i<w; ++i){draw((i, 0)--(i,h-1));}label("$A$", (0,0), SW, p);label("$B$", (w-1,h-1), NE, p);[/asy]
natural solution: There are 5 steps to the right, and 4 steps up. These 9 steps can be made in any order, so we can choose 4 of the 9 steps to be "up" in $\binom{9}{4} = \boxed{126}$ ways.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A B :: "nat \<times> nat"
and paths :: "(nat \<times> nat) \<Rightarrow> (nat \<times> nat) \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "A = (0, 0)"
and h1 : "B = (5, 4)"
and h2 : "\<forall> (x, y) (x', y'). paths (x, y) (x', y') = paths (x + 1, y) (x', y') + paths (x, y + 1) (x', y')"
and h3 : "\<forall> x y. paths (x, y) (x, y) = 1"
shows  "paths A B = 126"

assumes h0 : "A = (0, 0)"

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A B :: "int * int"
and count_paths :: "(int * int) \<Rightarrow> (int * int) \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "A = (0, 0)"
and h1 : "B = (5, 4)"
and h2 : "count_paths A B = (\<Prod>i \<in> {1..4}. (5 + i) div i)"
shows  "count_paths A B = 126"

 *)

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A B :: "int * int"
and paths :: "(int * int) \<Rightarrow> (int * int) \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "A = (0, 0)"
and h1 : "B = (5, 4)"
and h2 : "paths = (\<lambda>(x1, y1) (x2, y2). (fact (x2 - x1 + y2 - y1)) div (fact (x2 - x1) * fact (y2 - y1)))"
shows  "paths A B = 126"

 How many paths are there from $A$ to $B$, if every step must be up or to the right?[asy]size(4cm,4cm);int w=6;int h=5;int i;pen p=fontsize(9);for (i=0; i<h; ++i){draw((0,i) -- (w-1,i));}for (i=0; i<w; ++i){draw((i, 0)--(i,h-1));}label("$A$", (0,0), SW, p);label("$B$", (w-1,h-1), NE, p);[/asy] The final Answer is 126
 ### Proof
 There are 5 steps to the right, and 4 steps up. These 9 steps can be made in any order, so we can choose 4 of the 9 steps to be "up" in $\binom{9}{4} = \boxed{126}$ ways.
 *)

theorem
fixes A B :: "int * int"
and paths :: "(int * int) \<Rightarrow> (int * int) \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "A = (0, 0)"
and h1 : "B = (5, 4)"

 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
